security_audit.summary: All 661 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES. The skill is a documentation/reference guide for API design containing markdown guides, OpenAPI examples, and a local Python utility. No network operations, no credential access, no command execution. The static analyzer incorrectly flagged cryptographic algorithm names (RS256, HS256) in documentation as 'weak crypto', backticks in markdown as 'shell execution', and REST endpoint paths as 'system reconnaissance'.

content.user_title: Design and document RESTful and GraphQL APIs
content.value_statement: This skill provides comprehensive guidance for designing, documenting, and implementing modern APIs. It covers both REST and GraphQL paradigms with industry best practices, authentication patterns, and versioning strategies for production-ready API designs.
actual_capabilities: Create OpenAPI 3.0 specifications and Swagger documentation
Design REST endpoints with proper URL structure and HTTP methods
Define GraphQL schemas with types, queries, mutations, and resolvers
Implement OAuth 2.0, JWT, and API key authentication patterns
Plan API versioning strategies for backward compatibility
Generate consistent error responses and pagination patterns
limitations: Does not generate working API code or server implementations
Does not validate API security against production requirements
Does not integrate with live API testing tools
Does not generate client SDKs from specifications

use_cases.title: Create API specifications
use_cases.description: Design REST or GraphQL APIs with comprehensive OpenAPI documentation and authentication patterns.

use_cases.title: Document existing APIs
use_cases.description: Generate OpenAPI specifications from existing APIs and create interactive documentation.

use_cases.title: Write API documentation
use_cases.description: Learn best practices for writing clear API documentation with code examples and error guides.

prompt_templates.title: Design REST API
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a REST API for user management with endpoints for registration, login, profile management, and password reset. Include proper HTTP methods, status codes, and error response formats.

prompt_templates.title: Create OpenAPI spec
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an OpenAPI 3.0 specification for a blog API including posts, comments, and tags. Include authentication with JWT and pagination for collections.

prompt_templates.title: Design GraphQL schema
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a GraphQL schema for an e-commerce application with products, categories, shopping cart, and orders. Include proper input types and pagination.

prompt_templates.title: Plan API versioning
prompt_templates.description: Plan an API versioning strategy for introducing breaking changes to an existing v1 API. Include deprecation notices and migration paths.

output_examples.input: Design authentication endpoints for a REST API with OAuth 2.0
output: POST /auth/register - Create new user account with email and password
POST /auth/login - Authenticate and receive access token with refresh token
POST /auth/logout - Invalidate refresh token and end session
POST /auth/refresh - Exchange valid refresh token for new access token
GET /auth/me - Return current authenticated user profile
Use JWT bearer tokens with RS256 signing algorithm

output_examples.input: Create pagination pattern for large API collections
output: Cursor-based pagination recommended for large datasets
Include nextCursor and hasMore fields in response
Offset-based pagination for smaller, predictable result sets
Always include total count when possible
Limit default to 20, maximum to 100 items per page

output_examples.input: Design error response format for REST API
output: Include error code, message, and detailed field-level errors
Add request ID for troubleshooting and correlation
Include timestamp in ISO 8601 UTC format
Never expose sensitive data or stack traces in error responses

best_practices: Use consistent naming conventions, URL structures, and error response formats across all endpoints
Implement proper authentication and rate limiting to protect API resources
Document all endpoints with OpenAPI specifications including examples and error codes
anti_patterns: Avoid using verbs in URLs - REST APIs should use nouns for resources
Do not expose implementation details or sensitive data in error responses
Avoid deep URL nesting beyond 2 levels - use query parameters instead

faq.question: What is the difference between REST and GraphQL?
faq.answer: REST uses fixed endpoints with specific HTTP methods while GraphQL uses a single endpoint with flexible queries. REST is simpler for basic CRUD, GraphQL is better for complex data requirements.

faq.question: How do I version my API without breaking clients?
faq.answer: Use URL versioning like /v1/users or header versioning. Add new fields without removing existing ones. Provide deprecation warnings before removing endpoints.

faq.question: What authentication method should I use?
faq.answer: OAuth 2.0 for user-facing apps, JWT bearer tokens for APIs, API keys for simple service-to-service authentication. Always use HTTPS.

faq.question: How do I handle pagination in REST APIs?
faq.answer: Cursor-based pagination for large real-time datasets. Offset-based for smaller datasets. Include metadata with total count, limits, and pagination cursors.

faq.question: What status codes should I use?
faq.answer: 200 for success, 201 for created, 204 for no content, 400 for bad request, 401 for unauthorized, 403 for forbidden, 404 for not found, 429 for rate limits, 500 for server errors.

faq.question: How do I document my API?
faq.answer: Use OpenAPI 3.0 specification with descriptions, examples, and parameter details. Include authentication requirements, error codes, and response schemas for each endpoint.
